article.description: North Carolina ran the play only one time, good enough for another win over a No. 1 team.
article.headline: Final play works to perfection
article.story:
CHAPEL HILL, N.C. -- North Carolina ran the play only one
time, good enough for another win over a No. 1 team.

	   Rashad McCants hit a 3-pointer with 6.2 seconds left to give the
ninth-ranked Tar Heels an 86-83 victory over No. 1 Connecticut on
Saturday.

	   "That was the only time we ran that the whole game," North
Carolina coach Roy Williams said of the play that got McCants a
wide-open look from the left side. "When we called the timeout,
that's what we set up."

	   And it added to the tradition of Tar Heels basketball.

	   It was North Carolina's (No. 11 ESPN/USA Today, No. 8 AP) 10th win over a top-ranked team, tying the Tar Heels with UCLA for the most in college basketball history.

	   The latest one ended when Ben Gordon's 3-point attempt to tie
bounced off the rim, setting off a wild celebration. It seemed most
of the 21,750 in attendance at the Smith Center headed onto the court.

	   "That crowd deserved a great game," said McCants, who scored
27 points against Connecticut for the second straight year.

	   He tied the game at 83 with a 3-pointer with 1:15 left, then hit
the winner off the set play.

	   "It's about stepping up. Big players make big shots and I just
wanted to do that," McCants said. "Coach pulled my card and he
wanted me to take the shot. He had confidence in me and that's all
you can ask for in a coach."

	   In an ironic twist, North Carolina's win will likely move its
archrival, Duke, into the No. 1 spot in The Associated Press poll.
The second-ranked Blue Devils beat No. 4 Wake Forest 84-72 earlier
Saturday.

	   The Tar Heels (11-3) led by 16 points early in the second half
only to see the Huskies (14-2) take an 83-80 lead with 1:30 to
play.

	   "The first half was the best we played by far," Williams said.
"Early in the second half we played as badly as we have on the
offensive end. The good thing was we kept playing, we just couldn't
finish."

	   Connecticut, which had an 11-game winning streak snapped and
lost on the road as a No. 1 team for the first time in 12 games,
missed two shots after McCants tied it.

	   North Carolina ran the clock down from 30 seconds, and Raymond
Felton started his move with 10 seconds left and found McCants on
the left side for the game-winner.

	   "He rises in the big games," Connecticut coach Jim Calhoun
said of McCants. "He was immense today, especially when he was
naked and wide open."

	   Gordon took the ball down the left side after McCants' shot,
made one spin and missed a 3 that could have tied it.

	   "The play wasn't what we wanted but I got a decent look,"
Gordon said.

	   Jawad Williams had 18 points for North Carolina, while Melvin
Scott added 11. Sean May, limited to 22 minutes by foul trouble,
had seven points and 11 rebounds.

	   Emeka Okafor had 29 points, 13 rebounds and six blocked shots
for the Huskies, while Rashad Anderson scored 16 points. Gordon had
10 points on 3-for-14 shooting, seven rebounds and 10 assists.

	   Gordon had to assume the point guard role for Connecticut early
in the second half when Taliek Brown picked up his fourth foul.

	   "Ben did a great job at the point but I would have liked to see
him get more points," Calhoun said. "He just didn't shoot well
but he made adjustments well."

	   The Tar Heels held Connecticut scoreless for the final 3:50 of
the first half, using a 12-0 run to take a 50-36 lead.

	   The lead got to 16 points twice in the first two minutes of the
second half before Connecticut started to establish itself on the
boards. Okafor had four points of a 15-2 run that brought the
Huskies to 61-60 with 12:36 to play.

	   North Carolina, which was coming off a 90-84 loss at Maryland,
is 10-14 against No. 1 teams, and this win ends a streak of four
straight losses in those games.

	   "I told our guys that if you just believe then we can have a
fun, fun time in that locker room," Williams said. "And we did
have a fun time in there."

	   Connecticut was playing a Top 10 team for the second time in a
week. Last Sunday, the Huskies had a 40-point lead late in an 86-59
victory over then-No. 6 Oklahoma. This was the Huskies' second loss
in the Smith Center in two years. North Carolina won 68-65 last
season after opening the game with a 23-4 run.

	   "In the second half we just started playing basketball and got
the ball to Emeka," Calhoun said. "We displayed the heart of a
champion in the second half but we didn't finish it as we have to
to be a champion."
